question.title: Jakarta Persistence (JPA) Specification for a join
question.body:
I cannot get this JPA Specification to work for a simple join. I know the ""statusLookup.code" when mapping but does not work here. Does anyone know how to get it to work. Its a document class, a status class and the specification class. I have left out the decorators for the tables but if it wasn't for the specification then the code works.

public class Document {
  @Id
  @Column(name = "id")
  private UUID id;

  @OneToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
  @JoinColumn(name = "status_id", referencedColumnName = "id")
  private Status statusLookup;

  @Column(name = "document_description")
  private String documentDescription;
}

public class Status {
  @Id
  @Column(columnDefinition = "UUID")
  private UUID id;
   
  @Column(name = "code")
  private String code;

  @Column(name = "description")
  private String description;
}

public class DocumentSpecification {
  public static Specification<Document> isStatus(String status) {
    return (root, query, builder) -> {
      return builder.equal(root.get("statusLookup.code"), status);
    };
  }
}

answers.body:
I think the isssue is in:

builder.equal(root.get("statusLookup.code"), status);

root.get(...) only takes one attribute name. A dotted path won’t work, so Hibernate will complain it can’t find statusLookup.code.

use

public static Specification<Document> isStatus(String status) {
  return (root, query, cb) -> {
    var statusJoin = root.join("statusLookup"); // INNER by default
    return cb.equal(statusJoin.get("code"), status);
  };
}

If statusLookup can be missing, use a left join:

var statusJoin = root.join("statusLookup", JoinType.LEFT);

This should help you fix it nice

NB: sometimes the Lazy loading of a one to one will be eagered if badly made, so you will may be able to access directly without the join: chain two get. But and BUUUT if you aim for a Lazy loading try to be sure that is enabled properly

question_comments.body: This is new to me. Usually when class Status depends on class Document and is linkd 1:1 or n:1, simply loading class Document is enough to get all correlated instances of Status. In this case you're using lazy loading, so any call that would affect (read/write) statusLookup, would also cause statusLookup to be loaded from DB automagically in the background before access to statusLookup takes place. So basically there is no need for a join in any part of your code, JPA should handle all that by itself. You just run a 'SELECT' on Document and virtually will have the full Object
